text: English grammar lesson 26 topic modal
verbs expressing past possibilities many
of you know that I just took a vacation
the question is where did I go I'm going
to give you four clues and each time I
give you a clue you'll have the chance
to make one guess are you ready to start
I travelled by car before my trip our
family car had about 9,000 miles now our
family car has over 10,000 miles make
your first guess by completing one of
the sentences below my children came
with me now they're only three and five
that's a lot to handle so I was very
happy that the children's grandmother
came along with us
make your second guess by completing one
of the sentences below
where we went things were different and
yet the same comfortable and familiar
make your third guests by completing one
of the sentences below make your final
guess by completing one of the sentences
below the answer is Jennifer travelled
to her home state of Pennsylvania she
and her children visited relatives there
I live in Massachusetts now so we
traveled from here down to here both
states are on the East Coast but
Massachusetts is in New England and
Pennsylvania is considered a
mid-atlantic state my relatives are in
western Pennsylvania so how did you do
did you need all four clues to guess my
destination let's talk about the
language you used to make your guesses
perhaps some of your guesses sounded
like these
maybe she visited relatives it's not
likely she traveled far with two small
children in this lesson I'd like to help
you understand that these kinds of
guesses about the past can be expressed
another way those guesses can be
restated with modal verbs she may have
visited relatives she must not have
traveled far with two small children do
you see how the meaning hasn't changed
it's just a different structure please
understand that when you're 100% certain
about past events then no modal verbs
are needed for example look at these
four sentences they're facts Jennifer
was on vacation she took a trip last
week she was traveling she has returned
from her trip no modal's used but when
you're not 100% certain about past
events your first choice is to use words
and phrases to express your doubt for
example maybe perhaps it's possible it's
likely as you did in the game your
second choice when you're not 100%
certain about past events is to use
modal verbs such as must may might and
could let's pause and recall what you
know already about modal verbs
modal verbs have different uses we use
modal verbs to express ability things
that we can or can't do we use modal
verbs to express necessity things that
we should or shouldn't do right now
we're going to use modal verbs to
express possibilities possibilities in
the past when you don't know exactly
what happened and you have to guess
modal verbs will help you express how
certain you are we use different modal
verbs to express a high degree or low
degree of certainty most often we use
the modal verb plus a base verb this is
the structure when we're talking about
the present or the future for example I
can dance you should study but when
we're talking about the past there's a
different structure needed a past form
let me show you this structure this past
form sometimes also known as the perfect
aspect uses the modal verb plus half
plus the past participle here's an
example of the affirmative she may have
visited relatives an example of the
negative she must not have traveled far
with two small children note the
placement of not
there are different modal verbs to help
us express different degrees of
certainty if you're very certain but not
exactly 100% you can use must have or
the modal like expression had to have in
the negative couldn't have and must not
have are very strong couldn't have is
slightly stronger because it expresses
someone's belief that something was
impossible now if you're less certain
about a possibility may have might have
and could have are your choices there
about fifty percent or less certain in
the negative may not have and might not
have are your choices exercise one read
this statement then choose the more
logical guess
example you'll read the fact we woke up
early on the day of our departure but we
left the house rather late then you must
choose the more logical explanation
which is more logical A or B
Jennifer must not have finished packing
the night before or Jennifer must have
decided to take a long morning nap I
hope you agree that a is more logical
now you try number one fact we sat in a
lot of traffic both to and from
Pennsylvania can you guess why
the more logical explanation is be and
in fact that's the truth there were some
accidents along the way
number two fact I learned some
interesting history about the three
rivers of Pittsburgh can you guess how
you
while hopefully you agree that while
someone's on vacation doing research
isn't the best way to a spend time so be
is the more logical answer and in fact
that's the truth I did take a riverboat
cruise with my children number three
fact my son sneezed and coughed a lot at
his grandmother's house but not at other
relatives homes can you guess why
you
the more logical answer is be if you
have a cold it goes with you no matter
where you go the unfortunate truth is
that we discovered my son is allergic to
cats we didn't know that before exercise
to rewrite each sentence so that a modal
verb is used let's try an example
together first reread the fact we spent
a lot of time outdoors next we read the
guest hmm they probably had good weather
in Pennsylvania probably has a strong
degree of certainty so let's use must
they must have had good weather in
Pennsylvania
now you try number one fact my daughter
received a lot of clothes
read the guess and rewrite it with a
modal verb
it's possible expresses a low degree of
certainty we can say she may have gotten
them from an older cousin we can use may
have might have or could have and in
fact this is the truth
it's very common among American children
to receive clothes from an older cousin
or an older sibling number two fact we
decided to break the long drive into two
days
we can rewrite the guests as they must
have stayed in a hotel one night it's
also possible to say had to have stayed
three fact we saw a baby elephant
we can rewrite the guests as they might
have gone to the zoo might have may have
could have are all possible and in fact
we did go to the Pittsburgh Zoo
additional practice for this lesson is
available at English cafe comm my user
name is Jennifer ESL follow the direct
link listed in the video description
remember it's free to join that's all
for now thanks for watching and happy
studies
